awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Research in Machine Learning and Its Application
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is aimed at developing a data-driven machine learning research program accompanied by an integrated undergraduate educational curriculum in data science and machine learning. The research team, consisting of faculty from Benedict College, a historically black college and university (HBCU), University of South Carolina, and North Carolina State University with complementary expertise in optimization, control theory, statistics, applied and computational mathematics, and engineering  will develop new methods in machine learning and employ these methods in a variety of applications, including  modeling malaria epidemics and diabetes; discovering constitutive laws and mechanisms for some selected materials and life science problems such as modeling heart tissues and designing synthetic ion separating membranes; incorporating machine learning modules into a hybrid multiscale model for simulating angiogenesis (angiogenesis is the physiological process through which new blood vessels form from preexisting vessels, formed in the earlier stage of formation and development of vascular system) of various organs and tissue constructs in 3D biofabrication. Additionally this project will create an innovative training program to educate undergraduate STEM students and to retool affiliated faculty in Benedict College to prepare them for data science and artificial intelligence related jobs and for conducting research using data-driven approaches in the future. The computing and learning laboratory will provide the necessary computing facility for participating faculty and students to carry out the research as well as educational activities.  

The project team will focus on several application problems that can be solved and improved using data science and machine learning tools: (1) using a multi-objective optimization approach to improve machine learning outcome in clustering, feature selection, knowledge extraction, and ensemble generation in modeling malaria epidemics and diabetes disease; (2) using Grey models to improve predictions in financial analysis; (3) developing forecasting models for disease epidemics including malaria and other diseases; (4) discovering constitutive laws and mechanisms in selected materials and life science problems such as stress-strain constitutive relations based on deep neural networks for heterogeneous heart tissues and organs and ion transport mechanisms in synthetic ion separating membranes; (5) coupling machine and deep learning tools to calibrate interaction energies and accelerate Monte Carlo simulations in a hybrid multiscale model for angiogenesis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
NSF Project Outcomes Report

Project Title

Excellence in Research: Machine Learning and its Application

Principal Investigator: Negash Begashaw

Award Number: 1954532

Duration: 2020 - 2024

Funding Amount: $466,200

Goals and Objectives

  • Five research projects pertinent to applying neural networks and other machine learning methods to five important applications. 
  • Applications of our interest in the proposed research come from finance, epidemic outbreak prediction, materials research, and life science applications. 
  • As an undergraduate institution, our research is intimately tied to our educational mission. 
  • We have our students involved actively in the proposed research activities. Integrating students into the proposed research projects is the key to improve our research capacity in Benedict College. The proposed project generated materials for teaching data science and machine learning and develop fundamental methods in these areas. 
  • The overall framework of the approach and activities include curriculum development, experiential learning, and increasing capacity and resources via intense research collaborations around data science and machine learning theme. 

 

Key Outcomes

Curriculum Development/Course Offered

Created and implemented a new course (Introduction to Artificial Intelligence) in the       Computer Science program.

Offered a course to project participants at Benedict College on Mathematical Methods for Machine Learning. The course was offered three times online, once from USC and twice from Benedict College

Established a lab with powerful computers, that can be used for data science, machine learning, cyberphysical systems, and other tasks that require high performance computation.

Acquired a MATLAB license with all available toolboxes accessible to students and faculty.

 

Student Engagement

Conducted Summer Undergraduate Research for undergraduate students at Benedict College

Increased student participation among faculty and students in the area of machine Learning and data science

Conducted a nine-week training session for Python Programming for about twenty students.

Student Accomplishments

Five recent students who participated in the program are employed as Software Engineers at (Google, Service Now, Salesforce, Integer)

Three students have pursued their graduate study for Ph.D. (Clemson University, Iowa State University)

The above is not a complete list of all students who participated in the program.

Research Findings

Published 28 peer-reviewed articles, 11 conference papers and other publications.

Presented some of our findings at  conferences.

Collaborative Partnerships

Established partnerships with the University of South Carolina, North Carolina State University,      Clemson University, and Iowa State University

Launched a mentorship program connecting students with other professors in the Summer Undergraduate Research Institute (SURI) at Benedict College, resulting in summer internships for more than 50 students.

 

Broader Impacts

Diversity and Inclusion

Focused on underrepresented groups in STEM. All 35 students at Benedict College who participated in the project are minorities.

This project enabled concurrent and collaborative development and adaptation such programs as well as increase in capacity and share. The research generated capacity in developing high performance computing labs, develop courses and research and industry internships.

 

Students were provided with a learning path that matches real world problems with DS and ML solutions. This helped to develop new introductory courses in AI to prepare students for careers so that interdisciplinary problem solving will become part of their education, research, and future work.

 

 

Sustainability

The purpose of the proposed project entailed the long-term development of a laboratory collaboration which will evolve with the continuous evolution and dissemination of this research. The team collaborated with other faculty members in their respective departments and colleges. This progression will ensure that the developed facilities and the research will be sustained indefinitely.  Additionally, the department and school have committed resources to maintain the laboratories for teaching and research purposes, and they will serve as a conduit for collaboration with colleagues at other institutions.

Project participants have expressed strong desires to learn data analytics and machine learning techniques to incorporate into their research portfolio to advance their research methodologies. 

Secured additional funding from other sources to continue program initiatives post-grant.

Lessons Learned

Need for continuous feedback from participants to adapt and improve programs.

Future Directions

Expansion of the program to include more minority students at Benedict College.

Continued collaboration with colleagues at the University of South Carolina, North Carolina State University, Clemson University, and Iowa State University for student internships and graduate studies.

Conclusion

The project successfully met its objectives, demonstrating significant positive impacts on STEM education and student engagement.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Negash Begashaw

NSF Project Outcomes Report


Project Title


Excellence in Research: Machine Learning and its Application


Principal Investigator: Negash Begashaw


Award Number: 1954532


Duration: 2020 - 2024


Funding Amount: $466,200


Goals and Objectives

Five research projects pertinent to applying neural networks and other machine learning methods to five important applications.
Applications of our interest in the proposed research come from finance, epidemic outbreak prediction, materials research, and life science applications.
As an undergraduate institution, our research is intimately tied to our educational mission.
We have our students involved actively in the proposed research activities. Integrating students into the proposed research projects is the key to improve our research capacity in Benedict College. The proposed project generated materials for teaching data science and machine learning and develop fundamental methods in these areas.
The overall framework of the approach and activities include curriculum development, experiential learning, and increasing capacity and resources via intense research collaborations around data science and machine learning theme.






Key Outcomes


Curriculum Development/Course Offered


Created and implemented a new course (Introduction to Artificial Intelligence) in the Computer Science program.


Offered a course to project participants at Benedict College on Mathematical Methods for Machine Learning. The course was offered three times online, once from USC and twice from Benedict College


Established a lab with powerful computers, that can be used for data science, machine learning, cyberphysical systems, and other tasks that require high performance computation.


Acquired a MATLAB license with all available toolboxes accessible to students and faculty.





Student Engagement


Conducted Summer Undergraduate Research for undergraduate students at Benedict College


Increased student participation among faculty and students in the area of machine Learning and data science


Conducted a nine-week training session for Python Programming for about twenty students.


Student Accomplishments


Five recent students who participated in the program are employed as Software Engineers at (Google, Service Now, Salesforce, Integer)


Three students have pursued their graduate study for Ph.D. (Clemson University, Iowa State University)


The above is not a complete list of all students who participated in the program.


Research Findings


Published 28 peer-reviewed articles, 11 conference papers and other publications.


Presented some of our findings at conferences.


Collaborative Partnerships


Established partnerships with the University of South Carolina, North Carolina State University, Clemson University, and Iowa State University


Launched a mentorship program connecting students with other professors in the Summer Undergraduate Research Institute (SURI) at Benedict College, resulting in summer internships for more than 50 students.





Broader Impacts


Diversity and Inclusion


Focused on underrepresented groups in STEM. All 35 students at Benedict College who participated in the project are minorities.


This project enabled concurrent and collaborative development and adaptation such programs as well as increase in capacity and share. The research generated capacity in developing high performance computing labs, develop courses and research and industry internships.





Students were provided with a learning path that matches real world problems with DS and ML solutions. This helped to develop new introductory courses in AI to prepare students for careers so that interdisciplinary problem solving will become part of their education, research, and future work.








Sustainability


The purpose of the proposed project entailed the long-term development of a laboratory collaboration which will evolve with the continuous evolution and dissemination of this research. The team collaborated with other faculty members in their respective departments and colleges.This progression will ensure that the developed facilities and the research will be sustained indefinitely. Additionally, the department and school have committed resources to maintain the laboratories for teaching and research purposes, and they will serve as a conduit for collaboration with colleagues at other institutions.


Project participants have expressed strong desires to learn data analytics and machine learning techniques to incorporate into their research portfolio to advance their research methodologies.


Secured additional funding from other sources to continue program initiatives post-grant.


Lessons Learned


Need for continuous feedback from participants to adapt and improve programs.


Future Directions


Expansion of the program to include more minority students at Benedict College.


Continued collaboration with colleagues at the University of South Carolina, North Carolina State University, Clemson University, and Iowa State University for student internships and graduate studies.


Conclusion


The project successfully met its objectives, demonstrating significant positive impacts on STEM education and student engagement.
